Post_Title: Jesus sinned in Luke 19:29 when he commanded his disciples to steal a horse. This shows that Jesus was not without sin when he died.
post_text: The eighth commandment of the ten commandments is “Thou shalt not steal". This would imply that stealing is a sin. Therefore if Jesus stole a horse, then Jesus sinned and was not without sin when he died and could not be the Messiah as promised by the Jewish god in the old testament.

eh....i have to disagree. here's the passage: https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%2019%3A29-40&version=NIV

the implication seems to be that jesus knew that the horse's owners (who apparently had never ridden it) would be cool with "because jesus needs it" as an explanation, and he was right.

the most problematic part i see in the passage is when jesus said "If anyone asks you, ‘Why are you untying it?’" why "if"? isn't he omniscient?

If Jesus knows the owner, why not just go get the horse himself? If he knows the owner why not just tell his disciples to go find the owner and ask?

Knowing someone doesn't limit your ability to steal from them. If I know my neighbor has a truck in his garage and the key is on the dash, I can't send my brother to go get it for a joy ride. Doesn't matter that I know the owner. I never asked. The police would still consider this theft.

i never said jesus "knew" the owner(s) to any extent beyond which jesus/god "knows" all of his creations.

i'm saying that the implication is that jesus knew that the owners would be cool with giving up/lending the horse if the excuse was "because jesus needs it."

it's like how i don't know you personally. but i "know" that if i were to offer you a $20, you would take it.
I read this and nowhere could I see the owners agreeing to lend the horse.  The disciples said that he needs it and then took it, at no point does it say that they let them have it.

you're right...*technically*. what goes between verses 34 and 35 are what we're focused on.

it's possible that the disciples killed the owners and massacred the village and took a potty break on the way back to jesus and it's just that Luke (or whomever actually wrote this passage) didn't bother to describe the events.

technically the passage doesn't give enough details to let us determine whether or not the horse was stolen, as you pointed out.

but:

1) if the disciples had taken the horse by force, a fight would have ensued and that would have been noteworthy enough to mention.

2) if jesus had instructed them to steal, he would have expected pushback, in which case he would have instructed his disciples to put up a fight rather than just say "jesus needs it."

based on the events the passage describes, i think we have to infer that no violence was necessary. otherwise, we'd be engaging in a sort of "theft-of-the-gaps" fallacy.

Your point is that we should assume the best outcome because of the lack of explanation,
but this is written to make somebody seem good,  kind of as a biography or an eulogy,
many bad things are often omitted from those two and we could assume the same has been done here.

it depends on how you view the passage, book, or bible as a whole.

i don't see it as an account of actual events. if i did think it was, i might not take at face value that the disciple managed to retrieve a horse that wasn't his. i might not take at face value that jesus asked him to do that. i might not even take at face value that jesus existed to begin with.

but OP's claim that jesus instructed a disciple to steal presupposes that the people described in the passage cited actually existed and that the events described in the passage actually took place. he/she is arguing on those grounds, therefore i don't think it's appropriate to add stuff to the story that isn't explicitly stated.
